paragraphs.text: Cameron would rather look 'frit' than face a bashing from Farage.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Ed Miliband, Nick Clegg and Nigel Farage have each written to David Cameron saying they are willing to have TV election debates
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: even if
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: he doesn't take part
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Cameron's people insist he won't come on
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: unless the Greens are there too
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Listen carefully
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: there is a faint creaking noise, the sound of a politician trying to wind back the great clock of politics
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In Cameron's case, he wants it back to the happy days
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: before Gordon Brown conceded the prime ministerial veto on TV debates
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It might just work
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Rule one in any prime minister's handbook is never give up an advantage
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In an election, that's what being prime minister is - an advantage
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That's why it took 12 general elections between most voters having access to a television in 1964 and the first (and last?) television debate in 2010
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Yet
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: debates are as old as politics itself
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: putting them on TV has had that "well, obviously" feel to it ever since the first US presidential debate in 1960
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It must have helped perpetuate the brand, that first contest
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: for it was between the two men whose lives and deaths shadowed the rest of the American century: the beautiful young upstart John F Kennedy and the so much less telegenic, even rather sweaty, Richard Nixon
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Cameron's people have been trying to back out of TV debates in 2015 almost since the lights went down on the last debate of the last election campaign
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It has been a carefully played, inch-by-inch retreat covered by protestations of enthusiasm, framed in the context of a wider concern for the state of democracy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Last August he ruminated on the way they sucked the oxygen out of the last campaign (and poured a good deal of it into the Lib Dems' camp)
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Now he says he is standing up for the right of the Greens, excluded for- according to Ofcom - not being big enough
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Questioning the value of the debates is easy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The doyen of electoral coverage, David Dimbleby, who chaired the BBC session, said later that he thought they didn't let in as much light as when politicians were made to face the voters on their own in the kind of Question Time event that, as it happens, he also chairs
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: There' s no doubt that accidental encounters with ordinary people- Brown's "bigoted woman", or Margaret Thatcher being confronted over the sinking of the Belgrano - have earned a place in history as moments of truth that have told a bigger story
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: There is something rather odd about the"one of these people will be prime minister" hype before a debate
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: that has been widened to include Farage
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: , of course, the debates aren't about debating in the traditional sense of the word
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: even when they are between two very different versions of the future
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: as they were in Scotland
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: What really mattered in those brutal encounters between Alex Salmond and Alistair Darling was the extraordinary depth of Darling's antipathy to Salmond and, for a while, the unexpected haplessness of Salmond under pressure
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That first debate will always be remembered as the moment the rabbit bit the car
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: All the same, Cameron's opponents cannot take victory for granted
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They accuse him of running scared
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Twittersphere throbs with shouts of "frit"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It is a charge that might have a price for the Tory leader
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It will certainly disconcert his less politically savvy supporters
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But mainly it will just confirm the prejudices of those who were never going to vote Conservative anyway
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: What it does prove, if proof were needed, is that the Tories are running a core vote strategy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the broadcasters find the nerve to go ahead anyway, which is a punt in itself
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: an empty podium would not look good
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: try to imagine the view from the perspective of a Tory strategist
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the bill for looking frit is tiny compared with the enduring burden of being savaged by Farage
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: For Cameron, the strategist would reckon, it would be like being assessed for a job by someone who had watched you in conversation with the pub bore
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Putting the two together is on a par with divorce proceedings where the party who has walked out stands and shouts a string of excuses unconnected with the facts in a way that is somehow illogically appealing
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Just say you've gone off him!
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: And
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: of course, that's why it must be made to happen
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Let's hear Cameron talking to both wings of his party at once
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: And
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: just as importantly, please, please let's have the Greens in the room too
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: It really would be an outrage not to
paragraphs.label: assumption
